p: Bactericidal activity for most antibiotics depends on the bacterial growth phase, often requiring ongoing metabolic activity and division of bacterial cells [ 38]. Whether this is true for the EO components geraniol and terpinen-4-ol, however, is unknown. The kill-rate for cells in two different growth phases was therefore studied: exponential and stationary phase populations of B. cenocepacia strain LMG 16656 were challenged. Compared with the killing curves observed for stationary phase cultures treated with terpinen-4-ol (0.25%), log phase cultures are killed slightly more swiftly ( Fig 1). Approximately 180 min in contact with terpinen-4-ol was required to kill all log phase cells, whereas 240 min was required to completely eradicate B. cenocepacia in the stationary phase. In the case of geraniol (0.5%) treatment, complete kill was observed after 180 min for both growth phases ( Fig 2). After 30 and 60 min, however, stationary phase cultures experienced approximately only 1 log 10 reduction, whereas log phase cultures at the same time points reduced to 2 log 10 and 3 log 10, respectively.
